speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We will hear argument next in Case 09-400, Staub v. Proctor Hospital. Mr. Schnapper.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Oh, I'm sorry. I'm looking ahead. And, oh, I've got the argument wrong, too. We will hear argument in 08-1438, Sossamon v. Texas. You don't look like Mr. Schnapper. Mr. Russell.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Now, what would it be, Mr. Russell, if there were a suit under RFRA because a Federal penal institution was not allowing for the religious practices that the act protects?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: In a suit under RFRA, could there be -- would damages be an appropriate remedy?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, could we back up. You are saying you could get them against the Federal Government too, but the government doesn't think so?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But did it use such language as "appropriate relief"?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, that's the question. Our cases say it has to be clear to the State when they go into one of these schemes, it has to be clear what liability they are subjecting themselves to. And in these other cases I think it was clear. I don't think it's clear with simply the word "appropriate relief."

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: The contract analogy, I suppose, would provide that the meaning of the contract is interpreted against the drafter. Right?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes. So to the extent the State is arguing for a restrictive interpretation, it gets at least a little help from the fact that the Federal Government wrote the statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Russell, the State looks at this statute and says, oh, this statute preserves the PLRA, and under the PLRA there are no damages without having a physical injury. So putting the PLRA together with "appropriate relief," PLRA is telling us it's not appropriate relief when there is no physical injury.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But in the prison setting, then, isn't it an academic question, because there are not going to be damages anyway?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Does it include punitive damages?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Does it include punitive damages?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yeah, but -- but, I mean, that means either that the Federal Government -- that the State government is liable for damages just as municipalities are, or that municipalities are immune to suit for damages just as the States are. I mean, that -- you don't know which way that cuts, do you?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, maybe let's talk about them, then.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, except this would be a violation of a statute, not a violation of a constitutional right. So under Ex parte Young they couldn't necessarily get an injunction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, I can conceive of a case where -- where the State's violation of RLUIPA consists of a State statute that simply deprives the individual of his rights under RLUIPA. What State official would you -- would you sue? It seems to me you couldn't sue the State legislature, so it would make sense to have an injunction against the State.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Isn't it argued that a possible purpose of that was to make it clear that the Federal Government couldn't sue a State to recover money that had been given to it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: You addressed the -- the effect of the issue here on persons who are in State institutions other than penal institutions. What would be -- what's the effect of the issue here on land use restrictions? Are there many cases in which issues involving land use restrictions are -- are raised in litigation against the State as opposed to a municipality?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the answer to Justice Alito's question is that in the land use area, zoning for example, those are mostly cases against municipalities or counties?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Not against the State.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: The government is going to tell us that the standard for waiver with respect to the Federal Government is different from the standard with respect to the State. Do you -- I think that's what they are going to tell us. Do you agree with that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But it seems to me that the States are in need of special protection. With -- with the Congress, if it's a Federal immunity, the Congress can always -- always change its law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That just can't happen with the State.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It's the suggestion of the opposite that -- that I am trying -- I am trying to explore. You have your white light on.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Russell. Ms. Harrington.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Suppose Congress passes a statute that creates a private right of action against both the Federal Government and against the States and in both instances authorizes all appropriate relief. Are damages available in the action against the Federal Government as well as the State government?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Well, the State -- the State provision is a Spending Clause provision.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: And what about the Federal Government?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What sense does it make? Other than -- I know you are representing a client and so special pleading for your client is -- is to be expected, but I find that very difficult to accept. If "all appropriate relief" includes damages as against the State that accepts Federal money, then you know, what's good for the State should be good for the Federal Government.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But those cases did not involve States, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And I think that the -- the core question here is the State -- and Justice Alito just posed it: the State is being treated with less dignity than the Federal Government, because your position is that the Federal Government is shielded by its sovereign immunity, and you say the State is not.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But we are talking about general principles of interpretation and the proposition that we are suggesting is that the State surely should be entitled to the same dignity, the same protection against suits as the Federal Government, and you suggest just the opposite.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And it seems to me that's contrary to standard principles of the Federal -- of protecting the Federal balance.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But it's -- but it's only because they accept the funds at all that the Spending -- that the Spending Clause is even operative.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the waiver -- I mean, on the State side they can say it says "appropriate relief." All right; we accept that we are going to be vulnerable to an injunction suit. But we're the State and it's our treasury, and it is not appropriate relief. We didn't waive it. It's not -- doesn't say in the Spending Clause legislation that we open up our treasury.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The word "appropriate" -- the word "appropriate" would -- would suggest that to me. If -- if I'm a State attorney general, and I -- I know that the rule is sovereign immunity and -- and especially with regard to raids on the State treasury, I think it would be at least plausible that I would -- I would read "appropriate relief" not to include monetary relief. And we have said -- the language from our cases -- Lane says a waiver of sovereign immunity must be unequivocally expressed in the statutory text and will be strictly construed in terms of its scope in favor of the sovereign. That's -- that's a high test.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And -- and although I might sit down and come out with a conclusion after intensive study that yes, maybe the best reading of this statute is that it allows money damages, I find it hard to say that it is unequivocally expressed in the statutory text.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You -- you deny that it has to be unequivocal?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But that has nothing to do with whether the language is clear or not to constitute a waiver. There is no principle of law that you are articulating that says it -- it has to be -- this is not clear enough for the Federal Government, but it is clear enough for the State. "Appropriate relief" either has a meaning or it doesn't.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What do you say about -- I think I read in one of these briefs that what I think is the most relevant similar statute, RFRA, has been held not to encompass the same word -- not to encompass the monetary relief, and also there was some legislative history where people testified and told Congress at the time that the word "appropriate" won't encompass monetary relief. Am I remembering that correctly?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But then you're bracketing the State with counties and municipalities. It really comes down to a question -- who decides whether the state fisc is touched. And why isn't it most appropriate for this Court to say, Congress can call it either way, but our rule is, Congress, if you want to reach the State treasury, you have to say so explicitly. And then there is no doubt when the State enters a contract that it's going to be subject to money damages as well as injunctive relief.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Ho.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: If it is, why is injunctive relief included at all? Meaning, what you seem to be saying to me is that no relief should be appropriate, because no relief is clear whether it's injunctive relief or damages?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Some would say that injunctive relief attaches more to the public FISC then compensatory relief. Because future conduct or change of conduct can have an enormous intrusion on the public FISC, so why do we draw the line between saying one is more intrusive than the other?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I was looking at the cases the best I can at the moment. I think you might say that there are a lot of cases which interpret the word "appropriate relief" to include monetary relief. And then there is some that don't. And to get a rule out of them, you would have to say, well, they are looking to context. And in context it sometimes is clear, sometimes occasionally not. But here, isn't this and maybe this was asked, but I want your answer. The context here, the words appropriate relief, govern both the prison situation and the land use situation, don't they? You are given an action when the government through a general land use regulation infringes somebody's right to build, for example. Now, wouldn't that kind of interference with the use of property quite often and normally require some kind of monetary compensation? This isn't just the odd thing in a prison, where it's talking about it might be called building a religious building or building some kind of parking, all kinds of things that have monetary compensation. Do you see my question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I know, but isn't it the same word that governs both?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If it's the same word that governs both and if land cases very often involve claims for money, I would think that would cut against you. But that's why I ask. I want to get your response.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But there are loads of cases that have nothing more than appropriate relief and in those cases context makes it clear. The only one really I thought strongly -- your strongest case seems to me to be RFRA.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Uh-huh.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I mean, so often, what I'm thinking of, a church wands to build, and they can't because of a land restriction. And it turns out that that land restriction violates this statute. And in the meantime they have had to rent buildings, they have had to maybe build somewhere else and they have had to do all kinds of things that cost money. And that's why I would think in that context money would be a natural thing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: To fulfill appropriateness.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought a local government would be subject to damages. We are talking about the state.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So now we have three distinctions. With respect to land use discrimination, the Rehab Act would presumably apply. So the Rehab Act says compensatory damages are permissible for that kind of discriminatory claim, so now we have compensatory damages for that. We have, potentially, compensatory damages for local governments, but not for State or Federal level. We are chopping up the statute at each stage, correct? We are treating different defendants differently and different claims differently with respect to the relief that's permissible?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Could you explain why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: But equity permits money as well. Equity permits money as well.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Before you do that, Barnes and Franklin were cases involving implied rights of action; isn't that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Okay.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And I'm -- this one question may be covered, but can you give me any examples where States have turned down money under the Spending Clause, say we don't want it, the restrictions are too great? Does this happen all the time, or ever?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Where States tell the Federal Government: No, thank you, we don't want the money.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Under programs like this?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I mean other States -- they say, oh, the liabilities are just too great, we don't want it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What do you do with the practical problem that's been brought up that if a State is sued, it can release the prisoner, it can transfer the prisoner, and then no relief is appropriate? That the only way that the State is going to take its obligation seriously is if it's exposed to compensatory damages?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What's the inducement to do it more quickly rather than to delay, to remedy the wrong faster rather than to delay?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Uh-huh.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That's an ideal world, that they'll respond, but there is an allegation that some prisons wait until the eve of the trial after onerous discovery on the plaintiff and after enormous harm to plaintiffs, physical and otherwise, before they capitulate. So what's the inducement?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: To move faster.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Let me ask -- get this information from you. As I understand it, there are some cases that find the words "appropriate relief" in a statute to include damages and there's some that don't. Let's look at the ones that don't. There is some where it's pretty hard to do it because it's in a heading called "injunction," and that's obvious. But there are only two statutes, really, where the courts have ever held in significant numbers that the word "appropriate relief" does not include money damages. One is the IDEA, the Disabilities Act, and the other is RFRA. Is there anything else that you've come across?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, but are there any others? I mean, I just want to get down on a piece of paper what I have to look at.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. So you don't have any others, I'm judging from your hesitation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: You -- you have already addressed this but I think it's their -- the position of your friend on the other side of the case is that with the Spending Clause you have a contract. The State has some extra protection, and therefore we need not be quite so strict in -- in construing waivers -- waivers of immunity, because you have the contract. Can you comment on that argument? And -- and you might want to say that the Spending Clause is potentially so sweeping that the State should have special protection and we should be particularly careful about the clear statement rule. Or do you think the clear statement rule applies with equal force whether it's a Spending Clause or a direct regulation under say, the Fourteenth Amendment?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Ho.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Russell, you have four minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Was that contested in Barnes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Was the liability for compensatory damages contested in Barnes?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Just punitive. And there is a lot of discussion, the assumption that they were liable for compensatory, but it really wasn't litigated, was it?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
